props.synopsis: The 24-year-old is charged with two counts of attempted murder, two counts of assault and one count of possessing an object to be used to kill.

image.altText: woman runs in shade on Sydney beach

props.synopsis: A record spell of September heat is baking southern states, with temperatures as much as 18 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: A cool change is coming to south-eastern Australia — but it will get even hotter first

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A Canberra court hears details of a series of burglaries — including the theft of two French bulldogs, several Audis and other cars — involving two 20-year-old men, one of whom allegedly joked he was taking one of the dogs "hostage".

title.children: 'Simply reckless' men who stole two French bulldogs and several cars face Canberra court

image.altText: Court staff and a protective services officer carry the Big Orange painting wrapped in plastic into a truck.

props.synopsis: In 2007, a gallery assistant made a discovery that rocked the Australian art world and led to one of the most controversial, high-profile and enduring art mysteries.

title.children: How one of Australia's most controversial art mysteries unfolded

image.altText: A 3D printed oil pump jack in front of the OPEC logo.

props.synopsis: OPEC has run an oil cartel for decades, but as the world moves away from fossil fuels, could its influence be waning, asks Nassim Khadem.

title.children: '$4.7b in profits a day': A powerful cartel still controls the world's oil and is why you're paying more for petrol

image.altText: A hand holding a fuel nozzle putting petrol in a white car

props.synopsis: People are feeling the pinch around the country as national average petrol prices top 204.4 cents per litre. But where are you at in the price cycle?

title.children: With school holidays imminent for some, will petrol prices drop any time soon? Your capital city breakdown

image.altText: The castle at Disney World in Orlando Florida

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Extreme fire danger declared for NSW south coast, and black bear captured after shutting down Disney World rides. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: America's CBS News has shared footage of the female black bear that forced half of Disney World's Magic Kingdom to shut down. The bear was sighted in a tree, including at the Haunted Mansion and Pirates of the Caribbean rides. She has since been safely captured and is now being relocated to the Ocala National Forest in Florida. Disney says it has reopened the rides at the theme park.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Video shows safe capture of bear that forced Disney shutdown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police in Victoria and New South Wales are searching for a man who fired a gun when police attempted to arrest him at a property in northern Victoria yesterday. Stanley Turvey, who has distinctive tattoos on his face and body, is believed to be armed and police say he should not be approached. A warrant for his arrest was issued this morning. Police say Turvey was armed when Shepparton detectives arrived at a Katandra West property to arrest him around midday. Turvey was challenged by police to drop the weapon when he fired a shot into the air before fleeing the scene in a vehicle. He then stopped at a house in Youanmite and forced a man to drive him across the border to Finley in New South Wales. Turvey, who police say let the driver go in Finley and did not harm him, has been charged with kidnap over the incident. You can read the full story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police in two states searching for gunman wanted on kidnap charges

featuredLink.title: Police in two states searching for gunman wanted on kidnap charges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Danish court has ordered an artist to refund a museum which gave him 70,000 euros ($AU116,000) in cash to incorporate into artworks, after he produced blank canvasses entitled "Take the Money and Run". Jens Haaning, 58, was commissioned by the Kunsten Museum to reproduce two works using the cash — Danish kroner and euros — to represent the annual salary in Denmark and Austria. A Copenhagen court has ordered Haaning to refund the museum 492,549 kroner ($AU70,480), which is equivalent to the sum the museum had given him minus the artist's fee and the mounting cost. Museum director Lasse Andersson previously told AFP that he laughed out loud when he first saw the two blank canvasses in 2021, and decided to show the works anyway. He said they have a "humouristic approach" and were "a reflection on how we value work". But he said the museum would take Haaning to court if he didn't pay back the money, which he refused to do. Interviewed on TV2 Nord television, Haaning said the museum had made "much, much more" money than what it invested thanks to the publicity surrounding the affair.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Danish museum wants artist to pay back money after producing blank canvasses

image.altText: Russell Brand

props.synopsis: They're allegations even the most beloved of Hollywood A-Listers would struggle to explain away, but Russell Brand and his millions of online followers exist in a different dimension, far away from cancel culture.

title.children: It's too late to cancel Russell Brand — he did it himself a decade ago

image.altText: Russell Brand leaves the Troubabour Wembley Park theatre. He is wearing sunglasses at night.

props.synopsis: A woman who accused British actor and comedian Russell Brand of sexual and emotional abuse says his denial of the allegations is "insulting".

title.children: 'Laughable and insulting': Russell Brand accuser hits out at his denials in fresh interview

image.altText: Abandoned cars on the main island of Tongatapu in the Kingdom of Tonga

props.synopsis: The Kingdom of Tonga looks like paradise, but its lush coconut palms nurse a hidden problem. Now, the country is preparing to deal with this car-sized problem, before it's too late.

title.children: Tonga has tens of thousands of abandoned cars. Now there's a plan to crush them and ship them home

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

props.synopsis: X/Twitter owner Elon Musk says his social media company plans to start charging a small monthly payment to use the platform. And US stocks end little changed ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting this week. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk says Twitter moving to charge users, US stocks move sideways as investors await Federal Reserve rates decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As Michele Bullock begins her second day as Reserve Bank of Australia governor, the image-softening campaign continues. It's a momentus time, with Ms Bullock the first female governor in the central bank's history. The Reserve Bank review recommended a communications shake-up at the bank after former governor Philip Lowe's poorly chosen comments that interest rates were unlikely to rise until 2024. And the communications revolution has begun! First, soft questions from a junior reporter as Ms Bullock walked in the front door of RBA headquarters in Sydney yesterday, then a YouTube video where Ms Bullock explains how interest rates operate. Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan. And you can watch Ms Bullock's YouTube video below if you want to find out what the RBA does!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank seeks to soften its image as Michele Bullock takes over

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal opposition says it's the most credible path to net zero, while the federal government says it's an expensive fantasy. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has floated the idea of a fleet of small modular nuclear reactors to replace coal-fired power. But the government says it's unproven technology, with new estimates showing that going nuclear would cost nearly $390 billion. Here's more from my colleague Rachel Puppazoni on The Business.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government says nuclear 'fantasy' to cost $387 billion

featuredLink.title: Political Stoush over nuclear heats up, but will it be part of our energy mix

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This story is a must read as the world transitions from fossil fuels to renewable energy: the cost of cleaning up ageing oil and gas infrastructure. Around Australia's coastline there are around 1 million tonnes of pipelines, fixed rigs, and floating vessels. Much of the infrastructure is due to be decommissioned and operators are required to clean up the sites. Back in August 2009, the Montara wellhead platform owned by PTTP Australasia in the Timor Sea suffered a well head blowout that caused an uncontrolled leak of oil and gas. The spill was not contained until November2009, the worst oil spill in Australia's history. So could it happen again? As my colleague Linton Besser reports, while oil and gas firms are legally required to clean up their sites, some don't want to pay the cost, which is estimated at more than $60 billion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The risk of environmental disaster from old oil and gas infrastructure

featuredLink.title: 'The clock is ticking': Is ageing offshore oil and gas infrastructure an environmental risk?

image.altText: A composite image showing Netanyahu and Musk.

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has urged Elon Musk to strike a balance between protecting free expression and fighting hate speech after weeks of controversy over anti-Semitic content on social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter.

title.children: Israel's Netanyahu urges Elon Musk to balance free speech with fighting anti-Semitism

image.altText: Montara well head platform continues to burn

props.synopsis: In waters around Australia's coastline are about 1 million tonnes of pipelines, moorings, fixed rigs and floating vessels. Many are due for "decommissioning" and operators are contractually obliged to remediate the sites. But the cost is gargantuan, and not everyone wants to pay, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Our waters are awash with ageing gas and oil infrastructure. What happens when these behemoths are no longer needed?

image.altText: A heavily tattooed man wearing sunglasses is pictured sitting in a car.

props.synopsis: Police in Victoria and New South Wales are searching for a man who is on the run after firing a gun when police attempted to arrest him at a property in northern Victoria.

title.children: Police in two states searching for gunman wanted on kidnap charges

image.altText: A composite image of a Triton unmanned surveillance aircraft and a P-8 Poseidon

props.synopsis: Australia will upgrade its fleet of P-8 patrol aircraft so they can eventually fire missiles out to 1,000 kilometres, while also purchasing another long-range Triton drone from the United States.

title.children: P-8A Poseidon upgrade and fourth Triton drone part of $1.5b boost to RAAF

image.altText: Healthy juvenile wombat underneath a parent.

props.synopsis: It's barely detectable to the human eye, but a microscopic parasite has decimated wombat populations across south-east Australia. Now, researchers have a better idea of how outbreaks occur, as they continue working to find ways to rescue the iconic marsupial from a "horrible, slow death".

title.children: New research offers insights into how a deadly disease devastated a wombat population

image.altText: Woman smiling at camera near a bush

props.synopsis: It's an idyllic island that sits just off the coast of north Queensland, masking a dark past of subjugation, displacement and discrimination.

title.children: With social disadvantage 'spiralling out of control', many residents of this Queensland island hope a Voice will turn the tide

image.altText: Prisoners released during a prisoner swap deal between US and Iran, arrive at Doha International Airport.

props.synopsis: Five US citizens have left Iran and landed in Doha in a prisoner swap for five Iranians held in the United States, and the transfer of $US6 billion in frozen Iranian assets.

title.children: US prisoners 'finally coming home' in rare prisoner swap with Iran

image.altText: Justin Trudeau rises to make a statement in the House of Commons.

props.synopsis: Canada expels a top Indian diplomat as it investigates what Prime Minister Justin Trudeau calls credible allegations that India's government may have links to the killing in Canada of a Sikh activist.

title.children: Justin Trudeau says India could be behind killing of Canadian Sikh leader, expels top diplomat

image.altText: Li Shangfu salutes before delivering a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore

props.synopsis: Li Shangfu was only appointed defence minister six months ago but has become the second missing Chinese minister in two months after Qin Gang was stripped of the foreign minister portfolio, with questions of loyalty and corruption believed to behind his apparent ouster.

title.children: 'Disarray for Xi': A second senior Chinese minister disappears into thin air as Beijing cracks down on corruption

image.altText: Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate speaks to the media

props.synopsis: The Councillor Conduct Tribunal finds Tom Tate used ratepayer funds for two annual NRL club memberships and was reimbursed for donations in breach of the City of Gold Coast's expenses policy.

title.children: Gold Coast mayor charged ratepayers for Titans membership and engaged in misconduct, council watchdog finds

image.altText: A manicured hand holds a mobile phone in a black and white graphic.

props.synopsis: A NSW woman bugged by her spurned ex-lover describes feeling like she was in a film during the ordeal — and experts say her experience is not uncommon as offenders get better at using technology "as a weapon against women".

title.children: Stalking victim felt like she was 'in a Netflix movie', amid spike in tech-assisted tracking

image.altText: Kris holding medicine with a dog on an outdoor couch

image.altText: A graphic showing the silhouette of a man's head in front of a large eye.

props.synopsis: After Queensland passed new legislation, the Northern Territory is now the only jurisdiction in Australia where alleged sexual offenders cannot be publicly named until they are committed to stand trial.

title.children: 'Behind the times': NT becomes last jurisdiction with laws protecting the identities of alleged rapists

image.altText: Young man with medium length brown hair and sunglasses smiling with his arms up.

props.synopsis: As a landmark study finds 4 per cent of suicides are gambling-related, a family speaks out about the impact gambling had on their son, who also had depression and suicided 12 years ago.

image.altText: Bert Boere holding an air pollution report standing next to Chair of the group Carmen Largaiolli.
